content.webTitle: George Groves questions Chris Eubank Jr’s pedigree after ‘old man’ taunts

fields.headline: George Groves questions Chris Eubank Jr’s pedigree after ‘old man’ taunts
fields.bodyText: For the best part of an hour George Groves and Chris Eubank Jr went at it, trading barbs and verbal howitzers before boring into each other’s eyes – and souls – at the finale of a testy press conference. This, intriguingly, was not about flogging tickets. Both men already knew their WBA and IBO super-middleweight unification contest had sold out in seven minutes earlier on Tuesday morning. This was about squeezing and teasing potential pressure points before their fight in front of nearly 20,000 people at the Manchester Arena on 17 February – and both men were intent on causing more than superficial damage. “You’re an old man,” Eubank Jr sneered at his rival. “You’re not the fighter you used to be. You are pretty average, you don’t have much speed, your defence is poor and your stamina is lacking. You can’t compete with me. I am too young, too fresh, too powerful, too quick and too good.” The evisceration had barely got started. “This is my time,” he continued. “I am a different animal to a year or two ago but George is the same guy. I know what happened in training and when we sparred together – I know all about George as a fighter and a man. I know his weaknesses and strength. He will not handle the fire and the heat.” Then came the prediction: his opponent would not hear the bell for the 12th round. Groves, by turn, smiled and smirked and aggressively countered – not only questioning his opponent’s pedigree but his relationship with his father, Chris Sr, who he suggested cared more about fame than about his son. “Eubank’s camp are totally deluded,” Groves said. “He is fighting in a division he doesn’t belong in. He is a middleweight who punches from his hips with his chin up in the air. He’s terrific for a soundbite. It’s made him Instafamous but this is different.” Groves knows the public and bookmakers make Eubank Jr a warm favourite but he believes they have been duped by his rival’s padded CV and his bombastic behaviour, especially on social media. He protested, with some justification, that when it comes to size and boxing pedigree he has a definite edge. “I used to hear other boxers talk about levels and it used to frustrate me,” he said. “But now I understand: sometimes it doesn’t matter how much you prepare, there are just people you can’t beat. Sorry for Junior he is not good enough and he doesn’t have the pedigree. On the night I believe I’m unstoppable and you won’t see the 12th round. “I’ve won junior titles, ABA titles and boxed for England all over the world against future Olympic champions as an amateur – and then beat world-class fighters as a professional. People think he has phenomenal stamina, that I will fade and am going to get knocked out. He talks a good game. Let’s see if we can believe it. When he is being beaten badly, how is he going to cope?” As the war of words intensified, this onlooker’s eyes were diverted to some of Eubank Jr’s camp, who were wearing T-shirts with The Next Generation on them. It’s an easy distinction to make: Groves, the ageing fighter, versus the coming man. However Eubank Jr at 28 is only a year younger than his opponent and has only three fewer fights on his CV. Groves has more mileage on the clock than his opponent – and later, away from the TV cameras, he was more reflective about how his 30 professional fights may have taken their toil. He acknowledged he suffered a “rocky two years” after splitting with his trainer Adam Booth, during which time he lost twice to Carl Froch and then to Badou Jack, but insisted he had rebuilt and felt “unstoppable” since moving to be trained by Shane McGuigan. “I am an old man and sometimes I struggle to keep up with some of the youngsters on the circuits,” Groves said, smiling. “But at the same time, it is keeping me young. Fighting wise I feel rejuvenated and ready to roll.” Sometimes it can be hard to decipher fact from fiction in boxing. But if Groves is right, then Eubank – and the bookies – could be in for a rude awakening.
